Posts.Content: Grats on your decision and best of luck to you! I'm looking forward to finally getting a scheduled date myself and that may happen this week. I'm hoping once the surgery has been scheduled I will feel a little of the psychological weight lift off. I'm interested that you've had a PET and bone scan, an MRI and so many DREs, with a Gleason 6. I'm a Gleason 3+4 and so far both surgeons I've spoken with don't see the need for any additional investigation before surgery (I've had one DRE, a cystoscopy and the biopsy. I did get two opinions on the biopsy slides but that was not suggested by the docs). Max

Posts.Title: RALP op on 22nd April 2014

Posts.Content: Allen, lancepeace, Jim, thanks so much for your replies. Interesting that 0.4 is behind the curve -- so far I've trusted the team @ CoH to be first-rate in every way and really on top of the data. I presume they have data that supports 0.4, I'm speaking with them this week hopefully. I certainly don't want to take any unnecessary risks and I'm young enough and in good enough health to tolerate salvage therapy, I believe, very well. My recovery from surgery has been great, continence almost from the git-go and no major ED. Good point about insurance, Jim -- I figured it was expensive but didn't realize it could be that much -- WOW. I have good insurance, hopefully it won't be problem but these days it wouldn't shock me if there are caveats.

Posts.Title: Rise After Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Would love to hear your opinions on my case. Surgery recap: Last April, nerve-sparing da Vinci, final pathology showed tumor confined to prostate, 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all negative, one microscopic unifocal positive margin on right side, Gleason changed to 4+3, prostate 58 grams, tumor 15%. PSAs: June (@2 months after surgery).....<0.02 undetectable October (@6 months).....................0.07 November (@7 months)..................0.1 January (@9 months).....................0.15 My team says they typically consider a biochemical recurrence at 0.4; I've read elsewhere than many Urologists consider it at 0.2. Have any of you had a similar kind of situation after surgery -- if so I'd love to hear details. At what point was it considered a recurrence? What salvage treatment did you choose and how successful was it? How have you dealt with it mentally and emotionally? Very best wishes to each and everyone on this forum, Max

Posts.Title: Rise After Surgery

Posts.Content: From the studies I've read, drinking a glass before a PSA test wouldn't have any effect. However long-term daily use might indeed show a lower PSA reading (at least one study suggested that pomegranate might cause cell death). However the delta would likely be small. It seems like pomegranate "couldn't hurt" if you want to kill off a few stray cells, but there is no evidence to indicate that it would ever kill enough cells to really matter.

Posts.Content: Update: We had an initial appointment and were impressed. The hospital comes across as a well-organized, bustling medical center. Dr. Wilson did a great job answering our questions, anticipating most of them. The hospital has done over 7000 robotic procedures and he has done 2500. I particularly like his motivation to constantly optimize/improve the procedure. We're still in the decision stage but are leaning heavily toward CoH.

Posts.Title: Know These Surgeons?

Posts.Content: Just a quick update with some thoughts, six weeks post. Surgeon & Hospital The nerve-sparing procedure was performed by Timothy Wilson at City of Hope in the LA area. We drove from out-of-state two days before and stayed ten days after at a nearby hotel at the "cancer rate". Dr. Wilson, with over 2500 RALPs, did a great job IMO. CoH was professional, caring and particular. Recommended. Results Three hours in surgery, no complications. Nerves spared. Six incisions. Organ-confined, 15% cancer, 58 grams, Gleason 7 (4+3) upgraded from (3+4), one microscopic unifocal positive margin on the right side. 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all clear. Side Effects Other than some rare stress incontinence, bladder control has been perfect since day one. ED is too soon to tell, although recent "testing" over the last several days has been surprisingly successful -- not exactly the same as before, but in the same neighborhood. Taking 5 mg Cialis per day. Recovery Incisions look about 75% healed. I've lost 15 lbs and am in otherwise very good health. Returned to work (non-strenuous) at two weeks. Perineal pain comes and goes, nothing intense but sometimes very annoying. Bowels feel mostly back to normal as of this week, constipation also comes and goes. The biggest surprise is my overall energy level which, although improving daily, is currently at about 70-75% pre-surgery. I've been averaging 10-11 hours sleep vs. 7-8 before. I seem to tire out a bit faster in any event, although that's slowly improving as well. As of this week I can start to resume more normal exercise (I'm a runner) and I'm finally rid of the lifting restriction. Questions How long did it take you to get back to your pre-surgery energy level? I'm a little concerned about the positive margin, a bit glum when I saw that. The surgeon believes it is of little significance. It does change my 10-year non-recurrence from 90% to 86% (Sloan-Kettering). Have any of you had a single tiny positive margin of this nature? If it did reoccur, how soon did it happen, did you get salvage radiation and how did that go? My first post-surgery PSA is coming up and I'm somewhat nervous. And then every three months for the next two years. I've got to get my head around that and figure out a good strategy for dealing with some anxiety there. Any tips? Cheers, Max

Posts.Content: Scheduled for surgery (RALP) a bit less than a month from now at City of Hope! The surgeon is Timothy Wilson. I feel relieved and optimistic (ready to get it done!), although I have an intermittent sort of "calm anxiety" under the surface in anticipation of both the procedure and the recovery -- typical, methinks. If anyone has any specific words of advice regarding CoH -- or any other words of wisdom -- please chime in! We'll be there two days before surgery + eight days after (removal of catheter). Scheduled as his second surgery on a Wednesday. I'm a little worried about the drive back (11 hours), but I'll have a fully reclining seat in which to travel, so I think that will be OK.

Posts.Title: Questions for Surgeon

Posts.Content: I'm putting together questions for my local Uro. What I have so far is based on posts I've read here, input from my local support group, and Walsh's book. Would love feedback/additional suggestions if anyone has a moment! In your opinion, difference between robotic/open/laparoscopic -- pros/cons? Are you familiar with Patrick Walsh's book and what is your opinion of it? Number of surgeries performed: Total, per year, last year and type (open, larapro, robot)? How many surgeries does the hospital do per month/year? Patient mix in terms of stage and how many in my stage (T1C)? What are your clear margin rates per stage? % of your patients who have regained continence? % of your patients who have overcome ED? How do you reconstruct the urinary sphincter? I've read about a "Rocco stitch"? Who assists you in surgery? What days do you do surgery and how many do you schedule on one day? If I decide to go with an out-of-state surgeon, will you coordinate with him as my local specialist?

Posts.Signature: Nov 2013 local PSA 4.2, Dec 2013 5.04, DRE no lumps, cystoscopy normal PCa Dx Jan 2014 age 49, Adenocarcinoma in 2/14 cores (both right mid, 20-30%) T1C, Gleason 3+4=7, associated PIN, 40g, density 0.13, seminal vesicles normal 2nd Opinion biopsy Johns Hopkins Feb 2014, same cores, 1) 30% 3+4 and 2) 50% 3+3 Nerve-sparing da Vinci surgery April 2014 at City of Hope (Duarte, CA) Final pathology showed tumor confined to prostate 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all negative One microscopic unifocal positive margin on right side Gleason changed to 4+3, prostate 58 grams, tumor 15% Post-surgery urinary and erectile function excellent.

Posts.Title: Questions for Surgeon

Posts.Content: Any opinions on lymph node removal as a standard part of the robotic procedure? We've been told that removing some lymph nodes (Gleason 7 (3+4) diagnosis) improves one's odds. Have you had lymph node removal as part of the surgery and if so, did you experience any side effects or complications?
Posts.Signature: Nov 2013 local PSA 4.2, Dec 2013 5.04, DRE no lumps, cystoscopy normal PCa Dx Jan 2014 age 49, Adenocarcinoma in 2/14 cores (both right mid, 20-30%) T1C, Gleason 3+4=7, associated PIN, 40g, density 0.13, seminal vesicles normal 2nd Opinion biopsy Johns Hopkins Feb 2014, same cores, 1) 30% 3+4 and 2) 50% 3+3 Nerve-sparing da Vinci surgery April 2014 at City of Hope (Duarte, CA) Final pathology showed tumor confined to prostate 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all negative One microscopic unifocal positive margin on right side Gleason changed to 4+3, prostate 58 grams, tumor 15% Post-surgery urinary and erectile function excellent.
Posts.Title: Robotic Procedure and Lymph Node Removal

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply, Chuck! This is consistent with what the surgeon told us. Although he stated he would take more like 2-3 dozen of them (will have to check my notes to verify this), claiming that the data model suggests as much as a 10% risk decrease. The first surgeon we spoke with did not mention anything about lymph nodes.
Posts.Signature: Nov 2013 local PSA 4.2, Dec 2013 5.04, DRE no lumps, cystoscopy normal PCa Dx Jan 2014 age 49, Adenocarcinoma in 2/14 cores (both right mid, 20-30%) T1C, Gleason 3+4=7, associated PIN, 40g, density 0.13, seminal vesicles normal 2nd Opinion biopsy Johns Hopkins Feb 2014, same cores, 1) 30% 3+4 and 2) 50% 3+3 Nerve-sparing da Vinci surgery April 2014 at City of Hope (Duarte, CA) Final pathology showed tumor confined to prostate 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all negative One microscopic unifocal positive margin on right side Gleason changed to 4+3, prostate 58 grams, tumor 15% Post-surgery urinary and erectile function excellent.
Posts.Title: Robotic Procedure and Lymph Node Removal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter One risk that is seldom mentioned is removing lymph nodes sometimes causes lymphocele, the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the body cavity. Hi newporter and thanks so much for your reply! The surgeon said there was a small risk of swelling in the ankles, I presume that is related to the retention of lymphatic fluid. Do you -- or anyone reading this thread -- know of a case where a man developed swelling like that following removal of lymph nodes after prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for posting these reports -- this kind of thing really helps those of us who are pre-surgery and still weighing out options and so on. So glad to hear your husband is recovering well!

Posts.Title: Update 9 days post DaVinci op

Posts.Content: Hi George, So sorry to hear of your loss. A PSA test is quick and inexpensive enough that I don't grok why the industry seems to be moving away from early detection. Best, Max
Posts.Signature: Nov 2013 local PSA 4.2, Dec 2013 5.04, DRE no lumps, cystoscopy normal PCa Dx Jan 2014 age 49, Adenocarcinoma in 2/14 cores (both right mid, 20-30%) T1C, Gleason 3+4=7, associated PIN, 40g, density 0.13, seminal vesicles normal 2nd Opinion biopsy Johns Hopkins Feb 2014, same cores, 1) 30% 3+4 and 2) 50% 3+3 Nerve-sparing da Vinci surgery April 2014 at City of Hope (Duarte, CA) Final pathology showed tumor confined to prostate 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all negative One microscopic unifocal positive margin on right side Gleason changed to 4+3, prostate 58 grams, tumor 15% Post-surgery urinary and erectile function excellent.
Posts.Title: On a not so lighter note....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by white08gt has your Urologist talked to you about starting Hormone Therapy. I was started on HT about 6 weeks before starting SRT after rising PSA when it reached 0.11 Doctor wanted to hit hard with both barrels. radiation was not that bad, just a little burning toward the end of the 30th treatment. My Radiation Oncologist and I spoke about it and decided that, in my case, SR would be sufficient. My big concern with radiation is long-term toxicity, the way I understand it, >3 years out is when side effects might more likely present due to scar tissue and such. Hence I see SR certainly with some risk -- of course that risk is nothing compared to metastasis.
Posts.Title: Seeking Opinions -> PSA Changes After RALP

Posts.Content: I had RALP last April (details in sig), but PSA began to rise after surgery. CT and bone scans clean, no evidence of metastasis. Currently scheduled to begin salvage radiation in less than a month, however my latest PSA actually dropped. Surgeon thinks holding off on radiation for now makes sense. May get a new test that uses genetic markers in the tumor to assess risk of recurrence. PSA numbers: 03/2015 0.16 02/2015 0.17 01/2015 0.15 11/2014 0.10 10/2014 0.07 06/2014 <0.02 What do you think? Would you hold off on radiation with these numbers? Thanks in advance for your thoughts, Max
Posts.Signature: Nov 2013 local PSA 4.2, Dec 2013 5.04, DRE no lumps, cystoscopy normal PCa Dx Jan 2014 age 49, Adenocarcinoma in 2/14 cores (both right mid, 20-30%) T1C, Gleason 3+4=7, associated PIN, 40g, density 0.13, seminal vesicles normal 2nd Opinion biopsy Johns Hopkins Feb 2014, same cores, 1) 30% 3+4 and 2) 50% 3+3 Nerve-sparing da Vinci surgery April 2014 at City of Hope (Duarte, CA) Final pathology showed tumor confined to prostate 31 lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic soft tissue all negative One microscopic unifocal positive margin on right side Gleason changed to 4+3, prostate 58 grams, tumor 15% Post-surgery urinary and erectile function excellent.
Posts.Title: Seeking Opinions -> PSA Changes After RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH It may not hurt to wait another month and test again. But the generally accepted definition of "official" recurrence is 2 consecutive readings of 0.2 or higher. Your number can be rounded UP to give the full 0.2. But, since it is still kind of borderline, it might not hurt to wait another month. But, with a 4+3 involved, I would not wait much longer. If the next one does not fall below 0.14 (which would then round it DOWN to 0.1), I would strongly consider the salvage radiation. Good luck!! Chuck That's kind of what I'm thinking, although I wonder if I'm just putting off the inevitable. The way I understand it, a detectable reading means there are prostate cells of some kind producing PSA, and they must be either normal cells or cancer cells. Do you know if normal cells can even live outside the prostate? I was surprised to see the 0.16 -- I fully expected more like 0.19, e.g. about the same rate of increase. The 0.16 doesn't make sense to me.
Posts.Title: Seeking Opinions -> PSA Changes After RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 In my view, acting sooner is better than letting the returning cancer an opportunity to spread. In just 5 months, since Oct., 2014, your PSA has more than doubled (PSADT). That, in itself, should be a red flag to your doctor. Sometimes -- not always -- it's best to throw the protocol book out the window. That's just the opinion of one grumpy old geezer. Best of luck. Jim Sage information, Jim. I agree that my doubling time is a big issue here. Do you know if, at numbers < 0.2 and a 4+3, cancer is likely to metastasize? Or would one typically need to have a much higher cell population (and hence higher PSA) to start to see that happen?
